elements.head: Size Object
elements.text: Drag this box to change an object's size

elements.head: Inspector Button
elements.text: Click this button to open the inspector for an object

elements.head: Object List Button
elements.text: Click this button to see a list of objects by category
Warning: Saving this file will replace any #1-#9 arguments with their current values. This can be prevented by saving the file in Max 5 format before modifying.

elements.head: Prototype Catalog Button
elements.text: Click this button to see a catalog of prototypes for an object

elements.head: Palette Category Selector
elements.text: Choose a category of user interface objects by clicking on the name. Click All to see all objects or Recent to see objects you've made recently
Show the inspector for the selected objects

elements.head: New Patcher
elements.text: Create a new patcher window

elements.head: New Text
elements.text: Create a new text editor window

elements.head: New Table
elements.text: Create a new table editor window

elements.head: New Patcher From Template
elements.text: Create a new patcher using the chosen template file as a starting point
Paste the contents of the clipboard into a new patcher window
Open a new file browser window
Open an existing patcher, text file, or collective file
Open the source for a patcher in a text window

elements.head: Open Recent
elements.text: Open a recently used file
Close the current window
Permit a patcher loaded as an abstraction to be edited. If disabled, the current patcher window was not loaded as an abstraction.
Save the current window
Save the current window with a new name
Save the current window as a self-contained file or an application
Save the current window as a template to be used when making a new patcher
Assign MIDI input and output ports to channel ranges and letter abbreviations
Return to the standard menus
Configure document settings for printing
Print the current window
List of all the patcher files and external objects used by the current patcher in the Max window
Load an external object. This is normally done when you create a new instance of an object.
Quit the application
Undo the previous editing operation
Redo the previous editing operation
Delete the selection and copy it to the clipboard
Copy the selection to the clipboard
Paste the contents of the clipboard into the current window
Paste the contents of the clipboard into the current window at the location where you clicked
Delete the selection
Duplicate the selection
Select everything in the current window
Create an fpic object in the patcher with the image currently on the clipboard
Replace the currently selected objects with the object on the clipboard
Transform the currently selected objects into a subpatcher
Transform the currently selected subpatcher into objects in the current patcher
Show the Find bar in the current window
Select the previous item that matches the current Find criteria
Select the next item that matches the current Find criteria
After the scheduler has been stopped, restart it. This item is only enabled after a stack overflow has occurred.
Open another view of a patcher

elements.head: Lock / Unlock
elements.text: Lock or unlock the patcher window. If this is disabled, it means this patcher cannot be edited.
Open the object palette allowing you to choose a new object that will be created in the center of the patcher window
Change the visiblity of the background layer of objects in the patcher
Prevent the editing of the background layer of objects in the patcher, permitting you to place objects on top of the background layer
Open a resizable window in the bottom right corner of the patcher window allowing to zoom in and out and scroll the visible area of the patcher
Make patch cords visible when the patcher is unlocked
Make patch cords invisible when the patcher is unlocked
Switch between presentation and patching modes. Presentation mode is an easier way to create a user interface for your patcher
Move the selected objects' front-to-back ordering one step toward the front. If objects are selected and this is disabled, it means the objects are already at the front.
Move the selected objects' front-to-back order one step toward the back. If objects are selected and this is disabled, it means the objects are already in the back.

elements.head: Save File Browser Search
elements.text: Save the current search criteria as a search in your file listings.

elements.head: Remove File Browser Search
elements.text: Remove the currently selected search from your file listings.  You can only remove custom searches that have been added, built-in searches are not removable.

elements.head: Hide/Show Preview
elements.text: Change whether or not the preview pane is visible in the lower portion of the FileBrowser window.

elements.head: Edit Metadata for Selected Object
elements.text: Open the Metadata Editor window for the selected object.

elements.head: Reveal Selected Object
elements.text: Show the selected file in your file system using the Finder or Windows Explorer.

elements.head: Add Metadata
elements.text: Create a new metadata entry for this file.  You can then edit the metadata type (tag, author, or an arbitrary type of your choosing) and value.

elements.head: Remove Selected Metadata
elements.text: Remove the currently selected metadata for the object
Edit user interface and real-time performance settings
Open an inspector window to edit settings that apply to an entire patcher
Show or hide the patcher's grid lines when the patcher is unlocked
Constrain the movement of objects so they fall onto grid lines
Open a small window in the corner of a patcher allowing you to change the visible area of the patcher by dragging or changing the size of the blue outlined box
Match the width of a text object to the width of its current text. For non-text objects, Fix Width will return the object to its default size
When objects are selected, Align matches their closest sides. When a patch cord is selected, Align straightens it, routing it around boxes if necessary.
Open the inspector window for the selected objects, where you can edit attributes
Open a color palette for changing the basic color of the selected objects or patch cords
Edit an object's name for use with pattr objects or patcher scripting
Configure the default colors of patcher objects
Make the selected objects disappear when the patcher is locked
Make the selected objects visible when the patcher is locked
Move the selected objects ahead of all other objects. If this command is disabled, it means the selected objects are already at the front.
Move the selected objects behind all other objects. If this command is disabled, it means the selected objects are already at the back.
Set the selected objects to ignore mouse clicks
Set the selected objects to respond to mouse clicks
Move the selected objects from the foreground (default) layer to the background layer
Move the selected objects from the background layer to the foreground layer
Add the selected objects to the presentation, where their size and position can be changed independently
Remove the selected objects from the presentation
Save the selected object's settings so you can create a copy from the object palette or by applying to another object using the Prototype menu
Apply stored settings to the selected object
Show or hide the font panel to change font settings on the selected object or topmost window
Open a dialog where you can type in a message to send to the selected objects
Overdrive is a scheduler mode that runs timing objects in a high-priority thread, resulting in more accuracy and less interference from other computer tasks
When enabled, clicks in an inactive window operate the window without bringing it to the front.
Auto Fix Width changes the width of text object boxes as you type
When enabled, floating-point numbers are rounded when displayed if they are close to an integer value
When enabled, option-clicking on an object in a locked patcher brings up its help file. When disabled, this only happens in an unlocked patcher.
When enabled, bubbles appear to describe objects' inlets and outlets when you move the cursor over them. When disabled, the descriptions appear in the clue window.
Open the DSP Status window where you can change audio driver and performance settings.
Edit the mapping between dac~ and adc~ channels and device channels
Open the setup window for the currently selected audio driver
Open the File Preferences window where you can add folders to the Max search path.
When debugging is enabled, execution of a patch will stop at any active breakpoints.
Open the Debug window, which shows the current program state when stopped at a Break Watchpoint.
Open the Watchpoints window listing all currently active Break and Monitor Watchpoints.
When program execution is stopped, Step sends the next pending message out an outlet, then suspends execution again.
When program execution is stopped, Continue resumes normal execution. Execution may stop again if another Break Watchpoint is encountered.
When program execution is stopped, Abort cancels any further execution.
When program execution is stopped, Auto Step begins executing by triggering the next pending message every two seconds, permitting you to watch your patch in slow motion.
If a patch is executing, Pause stops it and shows where execution is suspended in the Debug Window.
Add a break watchpoint (which will suspend execution when debugging is enabled) to the selected patch cord.
Add a monitor watchpoint to the selected patch cord to record messages passing through it that you can observe in the Watchpoints window.
Remove the watchpoint from the selected patch cord
Disable the selected watchpoint
Remove all watchpoints from all patchers
Show the internal Max debugging control panel.
When Probing is enabled, Max displays signal or matrix data from the patch cord under the cursor in a locked patcher.
Show the Matrix Probe window that displays current matrix data transmitted through the patch cord under the cursor in a locked patcher.
Extras are helpful utilities. You can add your own by placing them in the extras folder inside the patches folder.
Close all open windows
Bring the window ahead of the topmost window in the window list to the front
Bring the window behind the topmost window in the window list to the front
Arrange windows in a cascade pattern
Arrange windows in a horizontal tile pattern
Arrange windows in a vertical tile pattern
Close any open subpatcher windows of the topmost patcher window
Move the window behind all other open windows
Reduce the window to the bottom of the screen
Toggle between full-screen and a window's normal size
Reduce all windows to the bottom of the screen
Re-open all minimized windows
Move all windows in front of the windows of other applications
Show the floating clue window, which must already be visible if you are reading this text
Show the Max window, which lists error messages and the output of the print object
Choose a window by name to bring it to the front
Open the help file for the selected object
Open the reference manual page for the selected object
Display a query performed on the selected object's name in a file browser window
Magnify the topmost patcher window by about 10 percent
Zoom out the topmost patcher window by about 10 percent
Restore the zoom level of the topmost patcher window to 100%. If this item is disabled, it means the window is currently shown at 100%.
Paste the contents of the selected file at the location where you clicked to show this contetual menu

elements.head: Pencil Tool
elements.text: Draw values into a table

elements.head: Select Tool
elements.text: Select a range of table values for copy and paste

elements.head: Line Tool
elements.text: Make a smooth linear ramp of table values

elements.head: Move Tool
elements.text: Scroll the displayed area of a table

elements.head: Order by Time
elements.text: Sort messages in the Max window by the order in which they were originally displayed

elements.head: Clear All
elements.text: Clear the entire contents of the Max window
Store arbtirary named data with an object
Add a new folder to the search path. Use the Choose button that appears to pick the folder.
Delete the previously added instance attribute that is currently selected

If the selected path is the last one in the list, Remove Path will delete it. Otherwise, Remove Path will clear its value but leave the path listed. In both cases, the path is removed from the search path.
Point out the object responsible for the selected message
Point out the object(s) being inspected
Menu items specific to the selected object
Store the current value as the saved value of the attribute, immune from any changes to the attribute's value
Remove a special saved value for the attribute
Open the inspector on the object that sent the currently selected message
Open the inspector on the object that received the currently selected message
Point out the object that sent the currently selected message
Show the next page
Show the previous page
Load a collection of object default settings
Save the current object default settings in a file
Print all of the current search paths in the Max window
Open the main start page for the Max documentation
Information about new features in Max 5
Information about bug fixes and new features in the current version
Main page for the Max tutorials
Main page for the MSP tutorials
Main page for the Jitter tutorials
Lists editing shortcuts in the patcher
Lists keyboard commands for making new objects in a patcher
Show an additional column in the inspector that displays the programmatic name of an object's attributes
Sets the selected attribute to its value when the inspector was first opened on the object
Places a sizing box around the selected objects permitting you to resize them as a group
Places a sizing box around the selected objects permitting you to adjust the spacing between them

elements.head: Object Column Heading
elements.text: Click to sort the window by object name

elements.head: Order Column Heading
elements.text: Click to sort the window by the order the message was posted

elements.head: Message Column Heading
elements.text: Click to sort the window by message text

elements.head: Message Order
elements.text: Shows the order in which the message was posted

elements.head: Slot Number
elements.text: An index number for the searchpath slot

elements.head: Slot Name
elements.text: Provides a label for the path that is added to Max's searchpath

elements.head: Folder Path
elements.text: Defines the actual path that is added to Max's searchpath

elements.head: Recursive Path
elements.text: If toggled to on, every sub-folder of the given path will be added. This can be very dangerous when adding an excessively large folder hierarchy, such the root of a hard drive or your Desktop.

elements.head: Column Heading
elements.text: Click to sort by this column or drag the column to rearrange it

elements.head: Index Column Heading
elements.text: Shows the order of messages up to the point where execution is stopped

elements.head: Patcher Column Heading
elements.text: Shows the name of the patcher in which each message is executed

elements.head: Sender Column Heading
elements.text: Shows the name of the object that is sending the message

elements.head: Receiver Column Heading
elements.text: Shows the name of the object that is receiving and executing the message

elements.head: Message Column Heading
elements.text: Shows the name of message being executed

elements.head: Arguments Column Heading
elements.text: Shows the arguments to the message being executed

elements.head: Monitor Watchpoint
elements.text: This watchpoint will print any messages travelling through the patch cord in the Watchpoints window

elements.head: Break Watchpoint
elements.text: This watchpoint (currently disabled) will suspend execution of your patch and show the current execution state in the Debugger window. In order for it to work you need to enable debugging in the Debug menu.

elements.head: Break Watchpoint
elements.text: This watchpoint (currently enabled) will suspend execution of your patch and show the current execution state in the Debugger window.

elements.head: Disabled Watchpoint
elements.text: This watchpoint is currently disabled

elements.head: Monitor/Break Watchpoint
elements.text: This watchpoint will print any messages travelling through the patch cord in the Watchpoints window and suspend execution of your patch and show the current execution state in the Debugger window.

elements.head: Number Column Heading
elements.text: This column shows the watchpoint number

elements.head: Action Column Heading
elements.text: This column shows the type of watchpoint: break, monitor, or break/monitor

elements.head: Sender Column Heading
elements.text: This column shows the name of the object that sent the message being watched

elements.head: Patcher Column Heading
elements.text: This column shows the name of the patcher containing the watchpoint

elements.head: Value Column Heading
elements.text: This column shows the last value observed for this watchpoint

elements.head: Count Column Heading
elements.text: This column shows the number of messages sent through this watchpoint

elements.head: History Column Heading
elements.text: This column shows the recent history of message values sent through this watchpoint

elements.head: Inspector Cell
elements.text: There are so many things you can do while trapped in a cell

elements.head: Attribute Menu Column Heading
elements.text: Click to sort by "natural" attribute order

elements.head: Attribute Menu
elements.text: Click to get a menu of attribute editing commands

elements.head: Attribute Column Heading
elements.text: Click to sort by attribute name or drag to rearrange this column

elements.head: Attribute
elements.text: Click to select this attribute -- you can also drag it into a patcher

elements.head: Attribute Description Column Heading
elements.text: Click to sort by attribute description or drag to rearrange this column

elements.head: Attribute Description
elements.text: Click to select this attribute -- you can also drag it into a patcher

elements.head: Attribute Value Column Heading
elements.text: Click to sort by attribute description or drag to rearrange this column

elements.head: Attribute Value
elements.text: Click to edit this attribute

elements.head: Browser Window Location
elements.text: Sets the default location of the File Browser window. You can change this setting simply by moving or resizing the file browser.

elements.head: File Browser Color: Stripes for odd rows
elements.text: Sets the color for the background of odd rows in the File Browser window.

elements.head: File Browser Color: Stripes for even rows
elements.text: Sets the color for the background of even rows in the File Browser window.

elements.head: Max Window Location
elements.text: Sets the location of the Max (Status) Window when launching Max. You can change this setting simply by moving or resizing the window.

elements.head: Max Window at Startup
elements.text: When enabled, the Max (Status) Window appears when Max starts up.

elements.head: Assistance Background Color
elements.text: Sets the background color (and transparency) used for Assistance and Layout Bubbles.

elements.head: Assistance Text Color
elements.text: Sets the text color used for Assistance and Layout Bubbles.

elements.head: Clue Window Annotation Color
elements.text: Sets the background color displayed in the Clue Window the the mouse is positioned over an Annotation.

elements.head: Clue Window Background Color
elements.text: Sets the background color of the Clue Window.

elements.head: Clue Window Text Color
elements.text: Sets the text color used in the Clue Window.

elements.head: Box Fade Time (ms)
elements.text: Sets the amount of time it takes for an object to fade from view when removed from a patcher window.

elements.head: Object Palette Background Color
elements.text: Sets the background color (and transparency) used for the Object Palette.

elements.head: Scroll Animation Time (ms)
elements.text: Sets the amount of time required for scroll animation events

elements.head: Recall Order
elements.text: Sets the order of recall of this parameter. Lower numbers are recalled first. The order of recall of parameters with the same order number is undefined.

elements.head: Path To Parameter
elements.text: This feature is debug-build only, so you will never see this message. If you insist, this is the moniker path to the parameter object from the top-level of the patcher hierarchy.

elements.head: Link Parameter Name to Scripting Name
elements.text: If enabled, the parameter's long name will be linked with the object's scripting name.

elements.head: Long Name
elements.text: The long name of the parameter. This name must be unique per patcher hierarchy.

elements.head: Short Name
elements.text: The short name of the parameter. This name is used for display in the user interface.

elements.head: Scripting Name
elements.text: The scripting name of the object. This name must be unique per patcher.

elements.head: Type
elements.text: The type of the parameter. In general, this will be Int (0-255), Float (32-bit float), Enum (enumerated list of values) or Blob (list). Some parameters do not support certain parameter types, in which case those types will be unavailable in the drop-down menu.

elements.head: Range
elements.text: The range of the parameter (for Int and Float types), or the members of the enumerated list (for Enum types). Range in unsupported for Blob parameters.

elements.head: Modulation Mode
elements.text: The modulation mode of the parameter. Available modes depend on the parameter's type. Modulation is unsupported for Enum and Blob parameter types.

elements.head: Long Name
elements.text: The modulation range of the parameter, if modulation is enabled.

elements.head: Initial Value Enabled
elements.text: If enabled, the parameter will be set to an initial value (as specified in the Initial Value column) when the patcher or device is loaded. Turn this on (or off, and then on again) to store the current value of the parameter as the initial value.

elements.head: Initial Value
elements.text: The parameter's initial value, if the Initial Value Enabled checkbox is enabled.

elements.head: Custom Units
elements.text: The string to use when displaying the parameter's value, if "Unit Style" is set to 'Custom'. Simple symbols or sprintf-style strings may be used.

elements.head: Unit Style
elements.text: Parameters have a number of built-in display styles for their data. Choose between them from the drop-down menu.

elements.head: Exponential Scaling
elements.text: When set to a value other than 1., the parameter's input and output values will be exponentially scaled according to the factor entered in this column.

elements.head: Steps
elements.text: The number of steps available between the minimum and maximum values of a parameter. For instance, if the parameter has a range from 0.-64., with Steps set to 4, the user can only set the parameter to 0, 21.33, 42.66 and 64.

elements.head: Units
elements.text: If the parameter uses a Custom Unit Style (see Unit Style), the value entered here determines the units displayed in the user interface.

elements.head: Linear Value
elements.text: For Int, Float and Enum types, the linear value (without exponential scaling) of the parameter.

elements.head: Value
elements.text: The parameter's value.
